title: Graded Prognostic Assessment for Gastrointestinal Cancer (GI-GPA)
description: Estimates survival in patients with gastrointestinal cancers and brain metastases. Uses 4 prognostic factors to provide risk stratification and guide treatment decisions for patients with brain metastases from GI cancers.

parameters.name: age_category
parameters.description: Patient age category with different prognostic implications

parameters.name: kps
parameters.description: Karnofsky Performance Status reflecting functional capacity

parameters.name: extracranial_metastases
parameters.description: Presence of extracranial metastases outside the brain

parameters.name: number_brain_metastases
parameters.description: Number of brain metastases identified on imaging

result.name: gi_gpa_score
result.description: Total GI-GPA score calculated from prognostic factors

ranges.interpretation: 3 months median survival. Very poor prognosis with limited treatment options. Consider palliative care focus and comfort measures. Discuss goals of care with patient and family.
9 months median survival. Below average prognosis. Consider limited aggressive interventions with focus on quality of life. Palliative radiation therapy may be appropriate.
12 months median survival. Moderate prognosis. Consider radiation therapy and/or surgical resection for selected patients. Systemic therapy may be beneficial.
17 months median survival. Best prognosis group. Consider aggressive multimodal therapy including surgical resection, stereotactic radiosurgery, and systemic therapy.

references: Sperduto PW, Mesko S, Li J, Cagney D, Aizer A, Lin NU, et al. Estimating survival in patients with gastrointestinal cancers and brain metastases: An update of the graded prognostic assessment for gastrointestinal cancers (GI-GPA). Clin Transl Radiat Oncol. 2019;18:39-45. doi: 10.1016/j.ctro.2019.06.009.

Sperduto PW, Chao ST, Sneed PK, Luo X, Suh J, Roberge D, et al. Diagnosis-specific prognostic factors, indexes, and treatment outcomes for patients with newly diagnosed brain metastases: a multi-institutional analysis of 4,259 patients. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys. 2010;77(3):655-61. doi: 10.1016/j.ijrobp.2009.08.025.

Sperduto PW, Yang TJ, Beal K, Pan H, Brown PD, Bangdiwala A, et al. Estimating Survival in Patients With Lung Cancer and Brain Metastases: An Update of the Graded Prognostic Assessment for Lung Cancer Using Molecular Markers (Lung-molGPA). JAMA Oncol. 2017;3(6):827-831. doi: 10.1001/jamaoncol.2016.3834.
formula: GI-GPA Score = Age points (0-0.5) + KPS points (0-2) + Extracranial metastases points (0-0.5) + Number of brain metastases points (0-1)
notes: Developed from multi-institutional cohort of 845 patients with GI cancers and newly diagnosed brain metastases
Applicable to various gastrointestinal cancer types including colorectal, gastric, esophageal, and hepatobiliary cancers
Score ranges from 0.0 (worst prognosis) to 4.0 (best prognosis)
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and patient preferences
Helps guide treatment selection and end-of-life decision-making
Useful for stratification in clinical trials involving brain metastases
Free online calculator available at brainmetgpa.com
Consider multidisciplinary team approach for treatment planning
